Assembling and operating a vertical hydroponic garden
"Setting up a vertical hydroponic garden" with the following subtasks:
Setting up a vertical hydroponic garden
subtasks: Research different vertical hydroponic systems (e.g., tower, A-frame, wall-mounted, NFT).
Select appropriate crops (e.g., leafy greens, herbs, microgreens). Also, note that some fruits like strawberries, tomatoes, and peppers can be grown in vertical systems with proper support.
Assemble the physical structure for the chosen system, including building towers, frames, or wall mounts. This could involve cutting, drilling, and assembling components.
Install grow lights and adjust their height relative to plant growth stages. This might require measuring and mounting the lights at the appropriate distance.
Plant the selected crops, using growing media like rockwool or coco coir. This involves germinating seeds, transplanting young plants, or managing cuttings.
Set up the water and nutrient delivery system, ensuring proper connections and circulation. For example, connecting a submersible pump to the reservoir and tubing to the plants.
Automate the system if desired, using timers, solenoids, and pH controllers. This may involve programming and connections.
Regularly monitor the garden for signs of nutrient deficiencies, algae growth, or pest issues. This requires inspecting plants daily or weekly.
Adjust the nutrient solution as needed by testing pH and EC levels, and making corrections to maintain optimal conditions.
Clean and maintain the system to prevent blockages or contamination. This involves periodically rinsing the grow area and refilling or replacing the nutrient solution.
